newsitem.title: USA: BEFORE THE BELL - Intel, Conrail surge.
newsitem.headline: BEFORE THE BELL - Intel, Conrail surge.

text.p: Intel Corp's shares remained the focus of intense buying preceding Tuesday's market open, the stock continuing a climb to record highs on last night's news of quarterly earnings that were far beyond expectations.
Ahead of the opening bell, Intel stock traded at 115-3/4, up 8-1/8 from Monday's Nasdaq close.
Immediately after Intel announced the third quarter results, the shares soared to 112 in after-hours trade.
The computer chip company reported per share earnings of $1.48, $0.23 above the First Call consensus estimate and up from the $1.05 per share nettedin the year-ago period.

Traders also said Conrail Inc shares climbed sharply after investors learned of CSX Corp's friendly agreement to merge with Conrail, a deal that values Conrail at $92.50 per share in cash and stock, or $8.4 billion.
Preceding the market open, Conrail shares rose 16 to 87, whille CSX stock was unmoved.

Earnings news drove Texas Instruments shares higher, the stock reaching 58, up 2-3/8, after TI announced third quarter operating earnings of $0.23 per share, before a $192 million charge, versus $1.48 in the year-ago period.
The results were slightly above expectations.
Also, VLSI Technology Inc rose to 18 from 15-3/4 after it reported third quarter income of $0.06 versus $0.35 in the year-ago quasrter.
Most securities analysts were expecting break-even to slight loss for the period.

Other stocks rose in sympathy with those bouyed by earnings news: International Business Machines added 1-1/4 to 130-7/8, Sun Microsystems added 1-1/8 to 69-1/2, Dell Computer Corp gained 2-1/4 to 87-1/8, Microsoft climbed 2-3/8 to 139 and Cisco Systems Inc was at 67, up 1-3/4.
Also, U.S. Robotics traded at 73-1/2 from 69-1/8.

Bay Network fell to 22-1/2 from 24 after announcing last night the resignation of chief executive Andrew Ludwick, news that was followed this morning by downgrades of the stock by Morgan Stanley and Smith Barney.
Morgan said it cut it to neutral from strong buy and a market source said Smith Barney dropped it to neutral from buy.
